attributes.title: Adverse Childhood Experiences: A Scoping Review of Measures and Methods

summary.value:
1.0	TITLE

Adverse Childhood Experiences: A Scoping Review of Measures and Methods

2.0 PROTOCOL INFORMATION

2.1 Contact Person

Canan Karatekin (karat004@umn.edu)

2.2 Authors

Canan Karatekin, Institute of Child Development, University of Minnesota
Susan Marshall Mason, Division of Epidemiology and Community Health, School of Public Health, University of Minnesota
Amy Riegelman, Social Sciences Libraries, University of Minnesota
Caitlin Bakker, Health Sciences Libraries, University of Minnesota
Shanda Hunt, Health Sciences Libraries, University of Minnesota
Andrew Barnes Department of Pediatrics, Medical School, University of Minnesota

2.3 Organizational Affiliation of the Review

University of Minnesota

2.4 Dates

Anticipated Start Date: 9/17/19 (decision to conduct the study)
Anticipated Completion Date: 3/1/20 (anticipated date to submit the first paper)

2.5 Funding Sources

None. 

2.6 Conflicts of Interest

None. 

2.7 Countries

United States

3.0 BACKGROUND

3.1 Review Question

The landmark 1998 study by Felitti and colleagues has generated a great deal of research establishing a robust connection between negative experiences in childhood and health status later in life. This impressive research has, in turn, popularized the concept of ACEs, and led to efforts by policy-makers and clinicians to prevent ACEs and mitigate their health impacts. 

However, a significant shortcoming of the literature emerging on ACEs is a lack of strong justification for the inclusion of certain risk factors and the exclusion of others from the list of early adversities. This lack of clarity stems from the foundation of this research area--namely the 1998 study that launched the ACEs field--which was largely exploratory and not designed to definitively define what “counts” as an ACE. This uncertainty has led to confusion about what ACEs are and what to do about them. The term “ACEs” and variants such as “early adversity” are widely used among researchers, practitioners, and policy-makers. However, the specific adversities included in these definitions vary widely, which, in turn, critically shape the results and the implications for intervention.

3.2 Review Objectives

We argue that the lack of clarity in the conceptualization of ACEs contributes to lack of well-established, empirically supported, and widely used interventions for ACEs and may drive discussion of potential interventions in some directions over others. Therefore, the main goal of this scoping literature review is to draw attention to the different ways ACEs have been defined since Felitti and colleagues’ 1998 study, the extent to which definitions differ depending on the nature of the sample, and the implications of these different definitions for intervention research. Quantitatively demonstrating the heterogeneity in definitions and pointing out the areas of overlap and disagreement across researchers is important for advancing the science of ACEs, because it makes visible the different assumptions that underpin research on this topic and emphasizes the need for deeper conceptual discussions of ACEs and clarity in the goals of this research. In turn, establishing a robust conceptual foundation for ACE research is essential to guide practitioners and policymakers toward more impactful interventions and policies.

In addition to quantifying the heterogeneity in ACE terminology, we will focus on several other methodological aspects of the studies to highlight important strengths, limitations, and implications for translation into action by researchers, practitioners, and policy-makers. We are particularly concerned with the gap between the uses of ACEs for public health purposes (e.g., public surveillance, policy development) versus screening and treatment of individuals, the lack of clarity in how socioeconomic status fits into this research, and the disproportionate focus on risk as opposed to protective factors in ACEs research. Uncovering trends over the past two decades will demonstrate the evolution of the list of ACEs, the primary research questions, and the variety and sophistication of research designs in this field. Finally, examining definitions and methodological features across different fields of study will contribute to greater interdisciplinary integration. 

4.0 METHODS

The review will be conducted in four steps. In Step 1, articles were selected for review based on the criteria under “Selection of Studies” in the next section and uploaded into Rayyan after duplicates were removed. 

In Step 2, pairs of team members will review the titles and abstracts of selected articles in Rayyan based on the inclusionary and exclusionary criteria listed in the following section. 

In Step 3, pairs of team members will review the full text of the articles to further ensure that they meet inclusionary and exclusionary criteria. Reasons for exclusion will be reported for this step in accordance with PRISMA guidelines.

In Step 4, pairs of team members will code the articles using the codes listed under “Data Extraction and Charting” in the next section using standardized data extraction forms. 

5.0 DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS

5.1 Selection of Studies

The initial search was implemented in Step 1 using the following databases, which represent psychology/psychiatry, medicine, education, and social work: Ovid MEDLINE, PsycINFO via Ovid, ERIC, Education Source, PAIS Index, CINAHL via EBSCO, Embase via Ovid, Scopus, and Social Services Abstracts.

The search strategy was designed to capture variations of the phrases “adverse childhood experiences” or “adverse childhood events” in the record title, abstract, keyword, and heading fields.

The time frame was from 1999 to 11/26/19 (we excluded articles prior to 1999 to allow a year for the 1998 article by Felitti and colleagues to start to generate additional research).

The following criteria will be used in Steps 2 and 3 to select studies from this initial set of articles. 

5.1.a Inclusion Criteria
- The study must include quantitative data collected from human participants
- The study must include a measure (1) that is described in terms of “adverse childhood experiences,” or “adverse childhood events, and (2) that lists risk factors, not symptoms or feelings about the risk factors (e.g., level of distress, PTSD symptoms).

5.1.b Exclusion Criteria

- We will exclude studies based solely on qualitative data, reviews, meta-analyses, case studies, and all “gray literature,” such as theses, abstracts, conference proceedings, brief reports, and brief communications. 
- We will exclude studies that refer to adversities but do not use the term “adverse childhood experiences” or “adverse childhood events” to describe their measures.
- Non-English language
- Published prior to 1999

5.2 Quality Assessment

In Step 2, all raters will first code the same 50 articles in Rayyan. We will conduct additional training as necessary until 80% agreement is reached across all raters on the same set of articles.

Next, pairs of team members will independently review the titles and abstracts of all selected articles in Rayyan to decide on eligibility for further review based on the criteria listed earlier. Decisions will be coded as Include (in the full-text review), Exclude (in the full-text review), or Uncertain. We will try to minimize the number of articles coded as “Uncertain” at this step and include articles for screening in the next step if it is doubtful whether the inclusionary criteria are met.

Reliability statistics other than the threshold needed to reach reliability will not be reported at this step, as the goal is to reach 100% agreement.

Uncertainties and disagreements between raters will be resolved by consensus or an independent tie breaker throughout the screening process and referred to the first or last authors as necessary until a consensus is reached. If uncertainties and disagreements cannot be resolved by consensus based on the title and abstract, the full text of the article will be screened in the next step.

A similar process will be used for Step 3, where determination of eligibility will be based on the full text of the articles.

In Step 4, team members will code eligible articles, with each article to be coded independently by two raters. For this step, we will calculate and report reliability using statistics that take into account chance agreement, such as kappa. Disagreements will be resolved by consensus. Codes that do not meet a minimum level of inter-rater reliability will be dropped. 

5.3 Data Extraction and Charting

In Step 4, we will code the following from the full text of the articles and any associated supplemental materials using standardized data extraction forms that have already been developed. These codes have been agreed on by the co-authors and piloted using a small number articles.

Depending on the time constraints, the number of articles to be coded in this step, and the number of raters, we may not be able to code all the items below. Therefore, we categorized the items in terms of order of coding, and we may divide up the results into several manuscripts. Items marked with *** will be coded first, followed by items marked with **, and then *

•	***Coder
•	***Title of the article 
•	***Last name of the first author
•	***Year of publication 
•	***Name of the journal
•	***Funding sources, whether there is a conflict of interest statement, whether any conflicts of interest were reported
•	***Core definition of ACEs.
•	***Researchers’ recommendations for translation to action (e.g., who or what needs to be the target of change)
•	**Main purposes of the study (e.g., to report prevalence/incidence, to relate to an outcome, to investigate the effect of an intervention in relation to ACEs, etc.)
•	**If the purpose was to relate ACEs to an outcome, type of outcome (e.g., mental or physical health problems, academic problems, etc.)
•	**Study design in relation to ACEs, based on “Framework for Considering Study Designs for Future Research Needs.”
•	**Characteristics of the participants (e.g., the country and type of institution from which they were recruited, race/ethnicity, age, gender, sample size).
•	**Assessment of ACEs
•	**Whether any statistics were reported on the reliability or validity of the ACEs scale for the sample in the study and if so, which types of reliability and validity were reported.
•	***Whether any protective factors were included in the design
•	*The role of socioeconomic status (SES) in the design (e.g., whether it was included as an ACE, as a covariate, or an outcome).
•	**Whether ACEs were analyzed in a cumulative manner, in subgroups based on discrete numbers of ACEs, or whether analyses focused on the effects of specific ACEs compared to others
•	*How SES was defined

5.4 Strategies for Synthesis

Results will be reported in accordance with PRISMA-ScR guidelines. We expect that we will present most of the data in a descriptive format using tables and figures.

Quantitative analyses of associations will be conducted as necessary, depending on the extent of variability in the data and the amount of missing data.

6.0 References

1.	Felitti, V. J., Anda, R. F., Nordenberg, D., Williamson, D. F., Spitz, A. M., Edwards, V., … Marks, J. S. (1998). Relationship of childhood abuse and household dysfunction to many of the leading causes of death in adults: The Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) Study. American Journal of Preventive Medicine, 14(4), 245–258. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0749-3797(98)00017-8

attributes.title: Why do we hate corrupt people but still act corruptly?
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value: Between-subjects. IV: Social Dominance Orientation score.

question2b.value: DVs: Scores on each of the factors of the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire and the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011).

question10b.value: Participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions: 1) They answered the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire, then a corruption perception questionnaire, then the Social Dominance Orientation and sociodemographic questionnaire; or 2) They answered the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011), then the corruption perception questionnaire, then the Social Dominance Orientation and the sociodemographic questionnaire.

question5b.value: Data will be collected online through an anonymous link advertised on social media.

question6b.value: Considering a .3 effect size, .80 statistical power and alpha error of .05 for conducting a Structural Equation Model with 3 latent variables and 22 observed variables, at least 119 participants are expected. This is the minimum sample size to detect the effect.

question7b.value: Reaching saturation point, i.e., less than 10 people taking part in the research weekly.

question1a.value:
1) Social Dominance Orientation will predict engagement in corrupt behavior assessed via the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011).
2) Social Dominance Orientation will not predict engagement in social norm breaking assessed via the items measuring it on the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire (Ferreira, Fischer, Porto, Pilati, & Milfont, 2012)
3) Social Dominance Orientation will predict engagement in corruption assessed via the items measuring it on the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire (Ferreira et al., 2012).

question3a.value: Check variables: "How much money does the deal involve?"; "How is your salary constituted?".

question1c.value: Structural equation modeling considering the items that constitute each construct.

question3c.value: IV: Social Dominance Orientation; DV: Engagement in corrupt behavior assessed either through Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire or the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011).

registration_responses.datacompletion: Yes, data collection is underway or complete
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1) Social Dominance Orientation will predict engagement in corrupt behavior assessed via the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011).
2) Social Dominance Orientation will not predict engagement in social norm breaking assessed via the items measuring it on the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire (Ferreira, Fischer, Porto, Pilati, & Milfont, 2012)
3) Social Dominance Orientation will predict engagement in corruption assessed via the items measuring it on the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire (Ferreira et al., 2012).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: Check variables: "How much money does the deal involve?"; "How is your salary constituted?".
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a: Between-subjects. IV: Social Dominance Orientation score.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: DVs: Scores on each of the factors of the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire and the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011).
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: Participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions: 1) They answered the Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire, then a corruption perception questionnaire, then the Social Dominance Orientation and sociodemographic questionnaire; or 2) They answered the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011), then the corruption perception questionnaire, then the Social Dominance Orientation and the sociodemographic questionnaire.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Structural equation modeling considering the items that constitute each construct.
IV: Social Dominance Orientation; DV: Engagement in corrupt behavior assessed either through Brazilian Jeitinho Questionnaire or the vignette proposed by Mazar and Aggarwal (2011).
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Data will be collected online through an anonymous link advertised on social media.

Considering a .3 effect size, .80 statistical power and alpha error of .05 for conducting a Structural Equation Model with 3 latent variables and 22 observed variables, at least 119 participants are expected. This is the minimum sample size to detect the effect.
Reaching saturation point, i.e., less than 10 people taking part in the research weekly.

attributes.title: A Scoping Review of Primary Care Models and Perforomance
attributes.withdrawal_justification:
I would like to withdraw this registration as some information are missing. I would like to submit another registration with full details.

Thank you

attributes.title: Contestation to Authority in Brazil
attributes.description: This project aims to assess if the "Contestation to Authority" factor of the Right-Wing Authoritarianism scale has distinct properties than its dismembered counterpart, i.e., the "Submission to Authority" factor.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value: Exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses will be conducted with the modified RWA items.

question2b.value: Exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses will be conducted with the modified RWA items.

question10b.value: Only data regarding RWA will be analyzed in the present study. However, other constructs will also be assessed: Sociodemographic data, Moral Foundations, Basic Human Values and Social Dominance Orientation.

question4b.value: Participants who are at least 18 years old are elligible to take part in the research.

question5b.value: An online link of the Qualtrics platform will be provided and advertised in social media, so data will be collected online.

question6b.value: The minimum expected sample size is 340 because it will have a item:participant rate of 1:10. 60% of the samples with 1:10 rate tend to produce correct factor solutions, which is an acceptable index (Costello & Osborne, 2005).

question7b.value: Reaching saturation point, i.e., no more than 20 participants take part in the research weekly.

question8b.value: Being less than 18 years old. Failing check-tests.

question7c.value: Those with more than 20% of missing data will be deleted (Schlomer, Bauman, & Card, 2010).

question10c.value: A Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin value of at least .70 is expected. Otherwise, the analysis will not be conducted.

question1a.value: After changing the grammatical objects of the items that compose the factor Contestation to Authority, its items will be clustered into the same factor of the Submission to Authority items. The grammatical objects of the Contestation to Authority items will be modified to "Authorities" and "Leaders".

question2a.value: No interaction effects will be analyzed.

question3a.value: The check questions are the following: How much is 1+1? What is the official language of Brazil?

question5a.value: A recent cross-cultural adaptation (Vilanova, DeSousa, Koller, & Costa, 2018) of the Right-Wing Authoritarianism scale (Duckitt, Bizumic, Krauss, & Heled, 2010) to the Brazilian context found a four-factor structure instead of the three-factor structure originally proposed. The items that originally composed the "Conservatism" factor were clustered into two different factors: Pro-trait Conservatism items clustered in one factor (i.e. Submission to Authority) and con-trait Conservatism items clustered in another factor (i.e. Contestation to Authority). It has been hypothesized that this might have happened due to the different grammatical objects that constitute the items of the Submission to Authority and Contestation to Authority factors (Vilanova, Milfont, Cantal, Koller, & Costa, 2019).

question1c.value: The modified items of the Right-Wing Authoritarianism questionnaire.

question2c.value: Exploratory factor analysis and Confirmatory factor analysis.

question3c.value: All items are DVs since we are conducting a factor analysis.

question5c.value: The cut-off loading for retaining the item will be .40.

The items that originally composed the "Conservatism" factor were clustered into two different factors: Pro-trait Conservatism items clustered in one factor (i.e. Submission to Authority) and con-trait Conservatism items clustered in another factor (i.e. Contestation to Authority). It has been hypothesized that this might have happened due to the different grammatical objects that constitute the items of the Submission to Authority and Contestation to Authority factors (Vilanova, Milfont, Cantal, Koller, & Costa, 2019).

registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: Exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses will be conducted with the modified RWA items.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c: Those with more than 20% of missing data will be deleted (Schlomer, Bauman, & Card, 2010).
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: A Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin value of at least .70 is expected. Otherwise, the analysis will not be conducted.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: Only data regarding RWA will be analyzed in the present study. However, other constructs will also be assessed: Sociodemographic data, Moral Foundations, Basic Human Values and Social Dominance Orientation.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: The modified items of the Right-Wing Authoritarianism questionnaire.
Exploratory factor analysis and Confirmatory factor analysis.
All items are DVs since we are conducting a factor analysis.
The cut-off loading for retaining the item will be .40.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants who are at least 18 years old are elligible to take part in the research.
An online link of the Qualtrics platform will be provided and advertised in social media, so data will be collected online.

The minimum expected sample size is 340 because it will have a item:participant rate of 1:10. 60% of the samples with 1:10 rate tend to produce correct factor solutions, which is an acceptable index (Costello & Osborne, 2005).
Reaching saturation point, i.e., no more than 20 participants take part in the research weekly.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: Being less than 18 years old. Failing check-tests.

attributes.title: Predictive associations between dispositional mindfulness dimensions and symptoms of anxiety and depression: A meta-analysis

q1.value: Predictive associations between dispositional mindfulness dimensions and symptoms of anxiety and depression: A meta-analysis

q3.value:
Several studies have indicated that dispositional mindfulness is cross-sectionally associated with symptoms of depression and anxiety.
In this meta-analysis we aim to respond to the following research question:
Do dimensions of dispositional mindfulness predict changes in anxiety and depression symptoms in samples without treatment?

q4.value: We expect that the predictive association between dispositional mindfulness and symptoms of depression and anxiety will be small and that it will be moderated by the type of mindfulness dimension, age, gender, and type of sample.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A meta-analysis will be conducted.
Correlation coefficients between the variables will be collected at the aggregate level.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: As this is a meta-analysis, data will be collected from eligible studies.

question.value:
Searches: We search in PsycINFO, PubMed, PsycArticles, and PsychologyDatabase.
No restrictions around publication year.

Types of study to be included: Longitudinal studies will be included.
In studies that examine the effects of interventions, only data regarding control groups without treatment will be used.

Condition or domain being studied: Anxiety and Depression

Participants/population: Participants are children, adolescents, and adults. 
Only are eligible humans without receiving a psychological intervention. Therefore, in studies focused on the effects of interventions, only data of participants in a control condition without interventions are used for the meta-analysis.

Context: Studies in which dispositional mindfulness and symptoms of anxiety and/or depression are measured at Time 1 and symptoms of anxiety and/or depression are measured at Time 2 or subsequent follow-ups.

Main outcome(s): Measures of dispositional mindfulness at least in the first wave:
o	KIMS
o	MAAS
o	FFMQ
o	CHIME 
o	AAMS 
o	Others that assess similar mindfulness dimensions
Measures of symptom of Anxiety and Depression (e.g., CES-D, DAS, BDI, BAI,  HADS).

Statistic data to be entered for analysis:
Correlations between time 1 mindfulness measures and Time 1 anxiety and depression, correlations between Time 1 mindfulness measures and Time 2 anxiety and depression, and correlations between Time 1 and Time 2 anxiety and depression.

Data extraction (selection and coding)
Criteria: 
Longitudinal study with at least two waves (time 1 and time 2)
Measures of dispositional mindfulness at least in first wave. We will include studies with measures of mindfulness facets such as
o	KIMS
o	MAAS
o	FFMQ
o	CHIME 
o	AAMS 
Measures of the outcomes (depression and/or anxiety) at least in two waves, being the first one simultaneous to the measure of dispositional mindfulness.
Sample characteristics:
o	 N >3 
o	Without treatment. Therefore, if it is a study with treatment, there must be a control group without psychological, pharmacological and / or educational treatment.

The full text of all articles identified from the search will be preliminarily reviewed by two independent trained reviewers for eligibility. In case of disagreement, a third reviewer will check the eligibility of the studies in consultation with the research team.
Researchers will extract the necessary data from the articles (the above indicated correlation coefficients and characteristics of the sample) when they are available.
When the data are not available, the authors will be contacted and invited to submit the necessary data.
Once the data are received, they will be recorded to analyze.
Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Kappa coefficient will be obtained to estimate interrater agreement.

Strategy for data synthesis: Data will be used at the aggregate level.

Analysis of subgroups or subsets: Several potential moderators will be examined: age, gender, clinical versus nonclinical samples, dimension of mindfulness, questionnaire used to assess dispositional mindfulness, etc.

q13.value: Not applicable. This is a meta-analysis

question.value:
Measures of dispositional mindfulness at least in first wave:
o	KIMS
o	MAAS
o	FFMQ
o	CHIME 
o	AAMS 
o	Others that assess similar mindfulness dimensions
Measures of symptoms of Anxiety and Depression (e.g., CES-D, DAS, BDI, BAI,  HADS).
Regressive coefficients will be estimated from correlation coefficients.

q22.value:
Cross-sectional studies will be excluded.
Samples receiving treatment will be excluded.

q23.value: Only studies with available data in the published articles or given by the authors of the articles will be used

q24.value: Several potential moderators will be examined: type of dimension of dispositional mindfulness, age, sex, clinical versus nonclinical sample, the measures used to assess depression and anxiety, etc.

attributes.title: Bugler, Healy, & McHugh; replication+ of Feng, S., D’Mello, S., & Graesser, A. C. (2013).  CREP Project Number: #19-55
attributes.description:
CREP Project Number: #19-55

This replication was chosen by Jack Bugler and Sinead Healy as the topic of their Final Year Project which is a necessary component of their undergraduate degree. Both undergraduates are in their final year of study in the course BA of Psychology and Sociology in The University of Limerick.
This replication was chosen by Jack Bugler and Sinead Healy as the topic of their Final Year Project which is a necessary component of their undergraduate degree. Both undergraduates are in their final year of study in the course BA of Psychology and Sociology in The University of Limerick.This page contains the materials and procedures for a replication+ of Feng, S., D’Mello, S., & Graesser, A. C. (2013) being conducted by as part of the final year projects of 2 University of Limerick students Jack Bugler and Sinead Healy.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun
